repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Problem:

Given that `vim.snippet.expand()` sets temporary `<tab>`/`<s-tab>`
keymaps there is no way to build "smart-tab" functionality where `<tab>`
chooses the next completion candidate if the popup menu is visible.

Solution:

Set the keymap permanent in `_defaults`.

The downside of this approach is that users of multiple snippet engine's
need to adapt their keymaps to handle all their engines that are in use.
For example:

    vim.keymap.set({ 'i', 's' }, "<Tab>", function()
      if foreign_snippet.active() then
        return "<Cmd>lua require('foreign_snippet').jump()<CR>"
      elseif vim.snippet.active({ direction = 1 }) then
        return "<Cmd>lua vim.snippet.jump(1)<CR>"
      else
        return key
      end
    end, { expr = true })

Upside is that using `vim.keymap.set` to override keymaps is a well
established pattern - no need for an extra snippet.config keymap DSL - and `vim.snippet.expand` calls made by nvim itself
or plugins have working keymaps out of the box.

comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -184,6 +184,23 @@ do
     end, { desc = 'vim.lsp.buf.signature_help()' })
   end
 
+  do
+    ---@param direction vim.snippet.Direction
+    ---@param key string
+    local function set_snippet_jump(direction, key)
+      vim.keymap.set({ 'i', 's' }, key, function()
+        if vim.snippet.active({ direction = direction }) then
+          return string.format('<Cmd>lua vim.snippet.jump(%d)<CR>', direction)
+        else
+          return key
+        end
+      end, { desc = 'vim.snippet.jump if active, otherwise ' .. key, expr = true })

comment_data.body: instead of dropping this , worth updating it with the example from your PR description?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -4551,16 +4551,6 @@ vim.snippet.active({filter})                            *vim.snippet.active()*
     Returns `true` if there's an active snippet in the current buffer,
     applying the given filter if provided.
 
-    You can use this function to navigate a snippet as follows: >lua
-        vim.keymap.set({ 'i', 's' }, '<Tab>', function()

comment_data.body: oh, there's already an example below at `:help vim.snippet.jump()` 👍
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -4551,16 +4551,6 @@ vim.snippet.active({filter})                            *vim.snippet.active()*
     Returns `true` if there's an active snippet in the current buffer,
     applying the given filter if provided.
 
-    You can use this function to navigate a snippet as follows: >lua
-        vim.keymap.set({ 'i', 's' }, '<Tab>', function()

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
        end, { silent = true, expr = true })
```

For test purposes the description is irrelevant, but I think we should set `silent` and `expr` like the default mapping does.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -18,6 +18,20 @@ local retry = t.retry
 describe('vim.snippet', function()
   before_each(function()
     clear()
+    exec_lua(function()
+      local function set_snippet_jump(direction, key)
+        vim.keymap.set({ 'i', 's' }, key, function()
+          if vim.snippet.active({ direction = direction }) then
+            return string.format('<Cmd>lua vim.snippet.jump(%d)<CR>', direction)
+          else
+            return key
+          end
+        end, { desc = 'vim.snippet.jump if active, otherwise ' .. key, expr = true })

comment_regular_data.body:
> The downside of this approach is that users of multiple snippet engine's
need to adapt their keymaps to handle all their engines that are in use.

To expand on that: Plugins could instead also add `vim.snippet` awareness by adding `snippet.active()` / `snippet.jump` calls into their respective versions of those methods if they wanted to make the setup easier for users.
That won't work, since `<tab>` is used to expand a trigger -- i.e., _before_ a "foreign snippet" session is active.

> That won't work, since `<tab>` is used to expand a trigger -- i.e., _before_ a "foreign snippet" session is active.

I don't follow. `<tab>` here would only jump if a vim.snippet session is already active. It won't expand snippets. 

If you setup `<tab>` to expand or jump with either vim.snippet or a foreign snippet engine then you already customised it and can account for both engines, no? 

I thought I understood your use case about using two engines in the same buffer at different times but looks like I'm missing something.

The point is that this configuration is not as trivial as your code example indicates. My best effort so far is a monstrosity, and I was hoping we wouldn't have to force this boilerplate on other users.

But no matter; I'll survive (and probably just disable the snippet LSP capability again).

> The point is that this configuration is not as trivial as your code example indicates.

Can you share your configuration or elaborate on how exactly you currently use vim.snippet + luasnip?
@mfussenegger Could we also piggy-back the changes from https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/31879 in this PR and document on how to remove/override these default mappings?
just a question - does this mean once this is merged, i can disable the super-tab functionality?

labels.description: Nvim defaults for options, colorscheme/theme, autocmds/events, etc.
labels.name: defaults

title: feat(snippet): set snippet keymaps permanent instead of dynamic
